author: Krisha Bhatt
content: In an exclusive interview with the Free Press Journal, Anitha Cadambi, a professor at The USC Gould School of Law in Los Angeles, California, provided valuable information about the various opportunities that international students can avail at the university. She also discussed the diverse array of programs offered by USC Gould for students seeking legal education.
title: Law expert discusses global legal education scope in US

author: Disha Jana
content: Lithuanian intelligence agencies have said in a report that Russia can wage war in Ukraine for at least two more years. The agencies wrote that Russian intelligence is driving efforts to evade the sanctions imposed on the country's defence industry after it invaded Ukraine. Lithuania will house US-made Patriot anti-air missile systems, stationed by NATO in 2024.
title: Russia can wage war in Ukraine for at least 2 more yrs: Lithuania

author: Disha Jana
content: India has deported the first batch of Myanmar nationals who entered the country illegally to flee surge in fighting between the junta and rebels there. Manipur CM N Biren Singh also posted a video showing the deportation. "Although India isn't a signatory to the 1951 Refugee Convention, it has given shelter...to those fleeing the crisis in Myanmar," he wrote.
title: India deports 1st batch of Myanmar nationals who entered illegally

author: Jayanta Deka
content: Seven Myanmar nationals who entered Manipur illegally were on March 8 deported with officials saying that it was the first batch of 78 foreigners to be deported in the next four days. An official source said that the Myanmar nationals were taken up to Moreh by a chopper from where they would be handed over to the Myanmar authorities.
title: Manipur begins deportation of Myanmar nationals

author: Disha Jana
content: US President Joe Biden joked that sometimes he wished he was "cognitively impaired" following his State of the Union address on Thursday. Biden's comment came as he was criticised in recent days for failing to undergo a cognitive test as part of his annual physical exam. He recently made multiple gaffes in his speeches amid concerns over his memory.
title: Sometimes I wish I was cognitively impaired: US President Biden

author: Satarupa Dhar
content: EAM S Jaishankar met with former Japanese Prime Minister Yoshihide Suga, who currently serves as the chairman of the Japan-India Association. Jaishankar expressed his pleasure at the meeting and commended Suga’s impactful leadership in advancing the bilateral relationship between India and Japan. EAM Jaishankar further appreciated his friendship and support for their partnership.
title: Jaishankar commends former Japanese PM Suga’s leadership

author: Medhaa Gupta
content: Minister of State for External Affairs V Muraleedharan said on Friday that he received the mortal remains of Indian national Pat Nibin Maxwell, who was killed in a missile strike in Israel, at Kerala's Thiruvananthapuram airport. He added that he paid his respect. "I share the deep sorrow and anguish experienced by his family members," he further said.
title: Mortal remains of Indian killed in Israel received by MoS Muraleedharan in Kerala

author: Satarupa Dhar
content: Former Maldivian President Mohamed Nasheed has voiced significant concerns regarding the ramifications of India’s boycott call on the Maldives, particularly in the context of tourism. Nasheed, currently in India, conveyed apologies on behalf of the Maldivian people. He emphasised their wish for Indian tourists to continue visiting the country.
title: Ex Maldivian President says people of Maldives are sorry

author: Abhinav Rattan
content: Bitcoin reached a new all-time high price of $69,255 on CoinGecko today before quickly dropping back down to $66,700. The top cryptocurrency's previous all-time high of $67,617 was notched in November 2021. Bitcoin made new highs on some exchanges like Coinbase on Tuesday before immediately plunging 14%, causing $1 billion in liquidations across the crypto market.
title: Bitcoin hits new all-time high before dropping again

author: Disha Jana
content: Irish citizens on March 8, which is International Women's Day, voted on whether to remove an 87-year-old reference in the country's constitution, which states that a "woman's place is in the home". Citizens also voted on whether a reference to marriage as the basis "on which the family is founded" should be removed from the constitution.
title: Ireland votes on removing constitutional reference to 'women in home'
